author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have read the package naming guidelines: https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment. You can edit blocking comments, adding `[noblock]` to them in order to unblock auto-merging.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->
This double acronym is really hard to understand.

> This double acronym is really hard to understand.

yes, but this is a package for people reaseaching computational electromagnetics (CEM), therefore the potential users will know it exactly~

Thats often the case though for everyone who wants to use an acronym. The problem is the whole ecosystem becomes incomprehensible to most people when everyone does that in their own specific field. Thats why the guidelines recommend against it.

Acronyms are mesnt to be for e.g. CSV where everyone knows what it is, not just a small group.
MOM should be fine, you use it so much. But the other acronym should be written out.

> Thats often the case though for everyone who wants to use an acronym. The problem is the whole ecosystem becomes incomprehensible to most people when everyone does that in their own specific field. Thats why the guidelines recommend against it.
> 
> Acronyms are mesnt to be for e.g. CSV where everyone knows what it is, not just a small group.

ok, got it. Thank you for your kind explain, I'll figure a suitable name.

title: New package: CEM_MoMs v0.0.1
